discussion.content: C D seems right.

C,D is only going to work if the CEO has the VPN on both the connecting device as well as the device acting as a router (phone).
A VPN in your mobile device establishes a secure tunnel between your phone and the VPN service provider. As the VPN application runs, it encrypts your mobile device’s outgoing traffic. But it won’t do the same for the device’s router facility. Hence, your mobile phone’s VPN can only protect the phone itself, not the other devices tethered to it. 
I still agree it is the best choice. As fury stated the CEO will not know how to configure EAP-TTLS

comments.content:
EAP-TTLS requires only server-side certificates. This could be a better choice than D.
EAP-TTLS (EAP Tunneled Transport Layer Security)
• Support other authentication protocols in a TLS tunnel
• Use any authentication you can support,
maintain security with TLS

discussion.content:
This is a Hotel AP, unsecure for public use: choose C, D
A. Change the connection type to WPA2 - can't re-configure hotel AP
B. Change TKIP to CCMP - can re-configure hotel AP
C. Use a VPN - should always do with public AP
D. Tether to a mobile phone - 2nd best choice
E. Create a tunnel connection with EAP-TTLS - CEO will not know how to configure
AC seems right

questions.question_text: A Chief Executive Officer (CEO) is staying at a hotel during a business trip. The hotel's wireless network does not show a lock symbol. Which of the following precautions should the CEO take? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Create a tunnel connection with EAP-TTLS
choices.A: Change the connection type to WPA2

questions.question_text: A help desk technician is trying to determine the reason why several high-level officials' account passwords need to be reset shortly after implementing a self- service password reset process. Which of the following would BEST explain the issue?

choices.A: The system asked for publicly available information

discussion.content: How would the passwords expire shortly after being reset? Don't think it's C
They mentioned "account passwords need to be reset SHORTLY AFTER IMPLEMENTING a self- service password reset process" so since they just implemented the SSPR maybe they misconfigured it?
Answer is D key words are self-service

initially thought D. But after rereading and re-rereading C is the only answer that is anywhere in the ballpark.

A. wouldnt cause for a password reset (unless pushed by company tech would know this)
B. would work, but it would be everyone in the company (not just high level)
D. would make sense if this was account lockouts instead (phisher is attempting logins after gathering info from the high level people)

C is the only thing that would force a password reset on the user end.
SSPR is likely part of larger push that isnt mentioned
A possible reason why the given answer is right, is because the newly implemented self service password reset might of been misconfigured wrong on the password age policy. Just a thought.
Think about whaling u will get answers

Self-service password reset (SSPR) is defined as any process or technology that allows users who have either forgotten their password or triggered an intruder lockout to authenticate with an alternate factor, and repair their own problem, without calling the help desk. I believe C is correct

No you're interpreting the question/answer wrong. The company recently launched a self service password reset system. This is a system that let's you reset your password using things like personal questions that only you know the answer to. If a spear phishing attack occurred, the attack was after personal info they could use to gain access to these high level accounts. And while yes, this can be considered whaling, whaling is a form of spear phishing and the question does not state these were executives...just high level.

A is wrong because while possible is less likely than our solution. It also does not explain why only the higher level accounts need resets and not everyone
B is again possible, but I think less likely
C is def wrong because if they just reset their passwords, why would they expire. It's only possible if the self service system was misconfigured and expired passwords on the daily or something like that
will go with given C, Spearphishing do not ask for reset passowrds. and also High level is whaling

I think D: "several high-level officials". (It is very unlikely that their pasword expires at the same time, AND when a pasword expires, you don't need a pasword reset service. That is only when you forget your pasword.

comments.content:
